column20: manot: "considered as expressing 'a set.' When more than one ten is expressed, fulu is used" (Safford 1904:100)
(trúiŭg l tëláel): Krämer (1919:331) assumes this to be influenced by Western languages; (dart l tëláel): Krämer (1919:331) assumes this to be influenced by Western languages

column19: Müller (1917:125f.): similar, but one power less
Eilers' list of numerals ends at 600
Carroll & Soulik (1973): same numerals (except for 10) up to 10^8
column20: hulu: Carroll & Soulik (1973:465) report hulu in enumeration and compounds only; mada: Carroll & Soulik (1973:465) report madaangahulu for objects
(aibu arańan): due to a gap in Kayser (1993) taken from Hambruch (1914:111); (arańa e arańan): beyond 10^6, counting returns to 1 and continues recursively (Kayser 1993:68)
[-]nguhul: Vesper (1970) reports siŋaul for 10 (but no higher power numerals)
tebwina: according to Bingham (1922:15) for 10 objects; teñaun: according to Bingham (1922:15) for 10 people (or 100 coconuts [p.17])

column19: for power numerals in specific counting systems, see Erdland (1906:204f.); analysis in Bender & Beller (subm.)
Eilers (1934:461-463) reports similar, yet more complicated numerals (except for 10) up to 10^9
column20: eisaek: Eilers (1934:462) reports sẹngeṵil for 10; eisik: Eilers (1934:462) reports sẹngeṵil for 10

column19: Eilers (1934:397) reports similar, yet more complicated numerals (except for 10), and up to 10^3 only

column20: eṅoal: according to Girschner (1913:171) for rapid counting and most objects; säk: according to Girschner (1913:171) for living beings
sḗïk: Jackson (1983:52) reports also [-]ngool for 10, besides [-]yik

column19: Quackenbush (1968:201-203) reports a pattern in line with Trukic (with 10^3 = ngaraj)
column20: ë auit: Quackenbush (1968:203) reports ngaraj for 10^3
eyáf: according to both Jackson & Marck (1991) and Fritz (1911) for units of 10 coconuts; [e]ghit: Fritz (1911:19) reports sél for 10^4; [-]púngút: Fritz (1911:19) reports äpingit for 10^5

column19: unclear whether Krämer's (1937) power numerals for 10^5 onwards apply also to Lamotrek, or only to Fais
for power numerals in specific counting systems, see Sohn & Tawerilmang (1976:255,394); analysis in Bender & Beller (subm.)
column20: [se]ig: Sohn & Tawerilmang (1976:255,394) also report -yaf (for bundles or groups of 10 (or 8) referring to coconuts, eggs, copra, etc.) and -ngaul (for groups of 10, each of which includes 8 or 10 members)

column19: for power numerals in specific counting systems, see Alkire (1970:10-13); analysis in Bender & Beller (subm.)

column20: sollop: power numeral for 10^5 presumably as in Lamotrek (Krämer 1937:411f.)

thḯg: Tetens & Kubary (1873:130) report sek for 10; thẻg: Tetens & Kubary (1873:130) report sek for 10; the bogṹ: Tetens & Kubary (1873:130) report seboukith for 100; thẻn: Tetens & Kubary (1873:130) report sangrass for 1000

column19: for power numerals in pair-wise counting, see Eilers (1935:380); analysis in Bender & Beller (subm.)
Eilers also renders numerals reported by Pickering, Hale, and  Hellwig
